00017 =head1 NAME
00018 
00019 LinearProgramming.pl - Macros for the simplex tableau for linear programming
00020 problems.
00021 
00022 =head1 SYNPOSIS
00023 
00024 Macros related to the simplex method for Linear Programming.
00025 
00026     lp_pivot_element(...); # find the pivot element from a tableau
00027     lp_solve(...);         # pivot until done
00028     lp_current_value(...); # given a tableau, find the value of a requested variable
00029     lp_display(...);       # display a tableau
00030     lp_display_mm(...);    # display a tableau while in math mode
00031     lp_pivot(...);         # perform one pivot on a tableau
00032 
00033 Matrix display makes use of macros from PGmatrixmacros.pl, so it must be
00034 included too.
00035 
00036 =head1 DESCRIPTION
00037 
00038 These are macros for dealing with simplex tableau for linear programming
00039 problems.  The tableau is a reference to an array of arrays, which looks like,
00040 [[1,2,3], [4,5,6]].  The entries can be real numbers or Fractions.
00041 
00042 Tableaus are expected to be legal for the simplex method, such as
00043 
00044     [[0,  3, -4,  5, 1, 0, 0, 28],
00045      [0,  2,  0,  1, 0, 1, 0, 11],
00046      [0,  1,  2,  3, 0, 0, 1,  3],
00047      [1, -1,  2, -3, 0, 0, 0,  0]]
00048 
00049 or something similar which arises after pivoting.
00050 
00051 =head1 MACROS
00052 
00053 =head2 lp_pivot
00054 
00055 Take a tableau, the row and column number, and perform one pivot operation. The
00056 tableau can be any matrix in the form reference to array of arrays, such as
00057 [[1,2,3],[4,5,6]].  Row and column numbers start at 0.  An optional 4th argument
00058 can be specified to indicate that the matrix has entries of type Fraction (and
00059 then all entries should be of type Fraction).
00060 
00061     $m = [[1,2,3],[4,5,6]];
00062     lp_pivot($m, 0,2);
00063 
00064 This function is destructive - it changes the values of its matrix rather than
00065 making a copy, and also returns the matrix, so
00066 
00067     $m = lp_pivot([[1,2,3],[4,5,6]], 0, 2);
00068 
00069 will have the same result as the example above.
00070 
00071 =cut
00072 
00073 # perform a pivot operation
00074 # lp_pivot([[1,2,3],...,[4,5,6]], row, col, fractionmode)
00075 # row and col indecies start at 0
00076 # ^function lp_pivot
00077 sub lp_pivot {
00078     my $a_ref = shift;
00079     my $row = shift;
00080     my $col = shift;
00081     my $fracmode = shift;
00082     $fracmode = 0 unless defined($fracmode);
00083     my @matrows = @{$a_ref};
00084 
00085     if(($fracmode and $matrows[$row][$col]->scalar() == 0)
00086          or $matrows[$row][$col] == 0) {
00087         warn "Pivoting a matrix on a zero element";
00088         return($a_ref);
00089     }
00090     my ($j, $k, $hld);
00091     $hld = $matrows[$row][$col];
00092     for $j (1..scalar(@{$matrows[0]})) {
00093         $matrows[$row][$j-1] = $fracmode ? $matrows[$row][$j-1]->divBy($hld) :
00094             $matrows[$row][$j-1]/$hld;
00095     }
00096     for $k (1..scalar(@matrows)) {
00097         if($k-1 != $row) {
00098             $hld = $matrows[$k-1][$col];
00099             for $j (1..scalar(@{$matrows[0]})) {
00100                 $matrows[$k-1][$j-1] = $fracmode ?
00101                     $matrows[$k-1][$j-1]->minus($matrows[$row][$j-1]->times($hld)) :
00102                     $matrows[$k-1][$j-1] - $matrows[$row][$j-1]*$hld;
00103             }
00104         }
00105     }
00106     
00107     return($a_ref);
00108 }
00109 
00110 
00111 =head2 lp_pivot_element
00112 
00113 Take a simplex tableau, and determine which element is the next pivot element
00114 based on the algorithm in Mizrahi and Sullivan's Finite Mathematics, section
00115 4.2.  The tableau must represent a point in the region of feasibility for a LP
00116 problem.  Otherwise, it can be any matrix in the form reference to array of
00117 arrays, such as [[1,2,3],[4,5,6]].  An optional 2nd argument can be specified to
00118 indicate that the matrix has entries of type Fraction (and then all entries
00119 should be of type Fraction).
00120 
00121 It returns a pair [row, col], with the count starting at 0.  If there is no
00122 legal pivot column (final tableau), it returns [-1,-1].  If there is a column,
00123 but no pivot element (unbounded problem), it returns [-1, col].
00124 
00125 =cut
00126 
00127 # Find pivot column for standard part
00128 
00129 # ^function lp_pivot_element
00130 sub lp_pivot_element {
00131     my $a_ref = shift;
00132     my $fracmode = shift;
00133     $fracmode = 0 unless defined($fracmode);
00134     my @m = @{$a_ref};
00135     my $nrows = scalar(@m)-1; # really 1 less
00136     my $ncols = scalar(@{$m[0]}) -1;  # really 1 less
00137     # looking for minimum value
00138     my $minv = $fracmode ? $m[$nrows][0]->scalar() : $m[$nrows][0];
00139     my $pcol=0;
00140     my $j;
00141     for $j (1..($ncols-1)) {
00142         if(($fracmode and $m[$nrows][$j]->scalar()<$minv) or $m[$nrows][$j]<$minv) {
00143             $minv = $fracmode ? $m[$nrows][$j]->scalar() :$m[$nrows][$j];
00144             $pcol = $j;
00145         }
00146     }
00147     return (-1, -1) if ($minv>=0); # This means we are done
00148     # Now find the pivot row
00149     my $prow=-1;
00150     for $j (0..($nrows-1)) {
00151         if($fracmode ? ($m[$j][$pcol]->scalar() >0) : ($m[$j][$pcol]>0)) { # found a candidate
00152             if($prow == -1) {
00153                 $prow = $j;
00154             } else { # Test to see if this is an improvement
00155                 if($fracmode ?
00156                         ($m[$prow][$ncols]->scalar())/($m[$prow][$pcol]->scalar()) >
00157                                    ($m[$j][$ncols]->scalar()/$m[$j][$pcol]->scalar())
00158                      : ($m[$prow][$ncols]/$m[$prow][$pcol] >
00159                      $m[$j][$ncols]/$m[$j][$pcol])) {
00160                     $prow = $j;
00161                 }
00162             }
00163         }
00164     }
00165     return ($prow, $pcol);
00166 }
00167 
00168 =head2 lp_solve
00169 
00170 Take a tableau, and perform simplex method pivoting until done. The tableau can
00171 be any matrix in the form reference to array of arrays, such as
00172 [[1,2,3],[4,5,6]], which represents a linear programming tableau at a feasible
00173 point.  Options are specified in key/value pairs.
00174 
00175 =over
00176 
00177 =item C<S<< pivot_limit => 10 >>>
00178 
00179 limit the number of pivots to at most 10 - default is 100
00180 
00181 =item C<S<< fraction_mode => 1 >>>
00182 
00183 entries are of type Fraction - defaults to 0, i.e., false
00184 
00185 This function is destructive - it changes the values of its matrix rather than
00186 making a copy.  It returns a triple of the final tableau, an endcode indicating
00187 the type of result, and the number of pivots used.  The endcodes are 1 for
00188 success, 0 for unbounded.
00189 
00190 Example:
00191 
00192     $m = [[0,  3, -4,  5, 1, 0, 0, 28],
00193           [0,  2,  0,  1, 0, 1, 0, 11],
00194           [0,  1,  2,  3, 0, 0, 1,  3],
00195           [1, -1,  2, -3, 0, 0, 0,  0]];
00196 
00197     ($m, $endcode, $pivcount) = lp_solve($m, pivot_limit=>200);
00198 
00199 =cut
00200 
00201 # Solve a linear programming problem
00202 # lp_solve([[1,2,3],[4,5,6]])
00203 # It returns a triple of the final tableau, a code to say if we
00204 #   succeeded, and the number of pivots
00205 # ^function lp_solve
00206 # ^uses set_default_options
00207 # ^uses lp_pivot_element
00208 # ^uses lp_pivot
00209 sub lp_solve {
00210     my $a_ref_orig = shift;
00211     my %opts = @_;
00212 
00213     set_default_options(\%opts,
00214                                             '_filter_name' => 'lp_solve',
00215                                             'pivot_limit' => 100,
00216                                             'fraction_mode' => 0,
00217                                             'allow_unknown_options'=> 0);
00218 
00219     my ($pcol, $prow);
00220     my $a_ref;
00221     # First we clone the matrix so that it isn't modified in place
00222     for $prow (1..scalar(@{$a_ref_orig})) {
00223         for $pcol (1..scalar(@{$a_ref_orig->[0]})) {
00224             $a_ref->[$prow-1][$pcol-1] = $a_ref_orig->[$prow-1][$pcol-1];
00225         }
00226     }
00227     
00228     my $piv_count = 0;
00229     my $piv_limit = $opts{'pivot_limit'}; # Just in case of cycling or bugs
00230     my $fracmode = $opts{'fraction_mode'};
00231     # First do alternate pivoting
00232     # Now do regular pivots
00233     do {
00234         ($prow, $pcol) = lp_pivot_element($a_ref, $fracmode);
00235         if($prow>=0) {
00236             $a_ref = lp_pivot($a_ref, $prow, $pcol, $fracmode);
00237             $piv_count++;
00238         }
00239     } until($prow<0 or $piv_count>=$piv_limit);
00240     # code is 1 for success, 0 for unbounded
00241     my $endcode = 1;
00242     $endcode = 0 if ($pcol>=0);
00243     return($a_ref, $endcode, $piv_count);
00244 }
00245 
00246 =head2 lp_current_value
00247 
00248 Takes a simplex tableau and returns the value of a particular variable.
00249 Variables are associated to column numbers which are indexed starting with 0. 
00250 So, usually this means that the objective function is 0, x_1 is 1, and so on. 
00251 This can be used for slack variables too (assuming you know what columns they
00252 are in).
00253 
00254 =cut
00255 
00256 # Get the current value of a variable from a tableau
00257 # The variable is specified by column number, with 0 for P, 1 for x_1,
00258 #  and so on
00259 
00260 # ^function lp_current_value
00261 # ^uses Fraction::new
00262 sub lp_current_value {
00263   my $col = shift;
00264   my $aref = shift;
00265   my $fractionmode = 0;
00266   $fractionmode =1 if(ref($aref->[0][0]) eq 'Fraction');
00267 
00268   # Count how many ones there are.  If we hit non-zero/non-one, force count
00269   # to fail
00270   my ($cnt,$row,$save) = (0,'',0);
00271   for $row (@{$aref}) {
00272     if($fractionmode) {
00273       if($row->[$col]->scalar() != 0) {
00274     $cnt += ($row->[$col]->scalar() == 1) ? 1 : 2;
00275     $save = $row;
00276       }
00277     } else {
00278       if($row->[$col] != 0) {
00279     $cnt += ($row->[$col] == 1) ? 1 : 2;
00280     $save = $row;
00281       }
00282     }
00283   }
00284   if($cnt != 1) {
00285     return ($fractionmode ? new Fraction(0) : 0);
00286   }
00287   $cnt = scalar(@{$save});
00288   return $save->[$cnt-1];
00289 }
00290 
00291 =head2 lp_display_mm
00292 
00293 Display a simplex tableau while in math mode.
00294 
00295     $m = [[0,  3, -4,  5, 1, 0, 0, 28],
00296           [0,  2,  0,  1, 0, 1, 0, 11],
00297           [0,  1,  2,  3, 0, 0, 1,  3],
00298           [1, -1,  2, -3, 0, 0, 0,  0]];
00299     
00300     BEGIN_TEXT
00301     \[ \{ lp_display_mm($m) \} \]
00302     END_TEXT
00303 
00304 Accepts the same optional arguments as lp_display (see below), and produces
00305 nicer looking results.  However, it cannot have answer rules in the tableau
00306 (lp_display can have them for fill in the blank tableaus).
00307 
00308 =cut
00309 
00310 # Display a tableau in math mode
00311 # ^function lp_display_mm
00312 # ^uses lp_display
00313 sub lp_display_mm {
00314   lp_display(@_, force_tex=>1);
00315 }
00316 
00317 # Make a copy of a tableau
00318 # ^function lp_clone
00319 sub lp_clone {
00320     my $a1_ref = shift;
00321         my $a_ref = []; # make a copy to modify
00322         my $nrows = scalar(@{$a1_ref})-1; # really 1 less
00323     my ($j, $k);
00324     for $j (0..$nrows) {
00325       if($a1_ref->[$j] eq 'hline') {
00326         $a_ref->[$j] = 'hline';
00327       } else {
00328         for $k (0..(scalar(@{$a1_ref->[$j]}) -1)) {
00329           $a_ref->[$j][$k] = $a1_ref->[$j][$k];
00330         }
00331       }
00332     }
00333   return($a_ref);
00334 }
00335 
00336 =head2 lp_display
00337 
00338 Display a simplex tableau while not in math mode.
00339 
00340     $m = [[0,  3, -4,  5, 1, 0, 0, 28],
00341           [0,  2,  0,  1, 0, 1, 0, 11],
00342           [0,  1,  2,  3, 0, 0, 1,  3],
00343           [1, -1,  2, -3, 0, 0, 0,  0]];
00344     
00345     BEGIN_TEXT
00346     \{ lp_display($m)\}
00347     END_TEXT
00348 
00349 Takes the same optional arguments as display_matrix.  The default for column
00350 alignment as "augmentation line" before the last column. It also adds a
00351 horizontal line before the last row if it is not already specified.
00352 
00353 =cut
00354 
00355 # Display a tableau
00356 # ^function lp_display
00357 # ^uses lp_clone
00358 # ^uses display_matrix
00359 sub lp_display {
00360     my $a1_ref = shift;
00361     my %opts = @_;
00362     my $nrows = scalar(@{$a1_ref})-1; # really 1 less
00363     my $ncols = scalar(@{$a1_ref->[0]}) -1;  # really 1 less
00364     
00365     if(not defined($opts{'align'})) {
00366       my $align = "r" x $ncols;
00367       $align .=  "|r";
00368       $opts{'align'} = $align;
00369     }
00370     my $a_ref = lp_clone($a1_ref);
00371     
00372     if($a_ref->[$nrows-1] ne 'hline') {
00373       $a_ref->[$nrows+1] = $a_ref->[$nrows];
00374       $a_ref->[$nrows] = 'hline';
00375     }
00376     display_matrix($a_ref, %opts);
00377 }
